docs.title: Overview

docs.text: DNS Summary A speed dial app of the Internet, contains mapping of websites names to IP address - don't need to memorize IP addresses What this is Domain Name System (DNS) servers store databases that contain mappings to websites' respective IP addresses How it works (high-level) Your devices is configured to point to a DNS server when a domain name is entered into web browser The device fetch the IP address from DNS server & route the traffic to that IP address Usually, the selected DNS server is on your local network, but it doesn't have to be Common pitfalls / misunderstandings Misconception 1 Misconception 2 Misuse or overgeneralization Issues with DNS DNS has no native ability to distinguish legitimate and malicious network traffic, will allow users to access websites even if it's compromised or contains malware An infected computer may change its DNS server to point to malicious ones, directing to harmful domains by attackers DNS sinkhole is mean to mitigate these situations Related concepts DNS sinkhole References catchpoint DNS network guide
docs.title: DNS

docs.text: Offensive Security This section contains all (definitely not) the knowledge and techniques used by attackers to gain access/control. For each attack types/methods, there'll be a tooling sub-section which explain in depth the tools and its functionality
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: Defensive Security This section contains all (definitely not) the knowledge and techniques used by defenders to prevent, deter and minimize impacts caused by attackers.
docs.title: Overview

docs.title: Defensive Security

docs.text: DNS Sinkhole Summary A DNS sinkhole is used to blocked malicious DNS request What this is Works by intercepting DNS queries, compare them to dynamic list of known malicious domains If query attempts resolve to a bad domain, then route the traffic to a null route How it works (high-level) For general malicious/fishy websites For example, there's a known bad website called malware.com points to 1.1.1.1 To stop traffic from coming there, we configure our DNS server to point to 127.0.0.1 (our local IP address) if receives a query from malware.com For advertisements Your device queries a DNS server to resolve domain names into IP address However, websites also load third party ads and trackers, requiring additional DNS lookups to advertisers domains A configured DNS sinkhole allow us to intercept and block the unwanted queries, returning a null IP address to our browser Issues with DNS Sinkhole Won't block all ads or malcious websites, ONLY stops DNS-based threats Potential false positives or incompelete database of malicious/ads sites No native alerting Related concepts DNS References Blog post on removing ads through DNS sinkhole catchpoint DNS network guide
docs.title: dns-sinkhole

docs.text: YAML (YAML Ain't Markup Language) Definition: A human-readable data serialization language used for config files and data exchange. Applications : - Allow humans to easily read or create config files - Typically store things a program would need at run time, without needing to hard code the values ELIF: A general file format to store structured data that's way more readable to humans Do not confuse with: - YAML is a superset of JSON, technically a YAML parser can understand JSON - YAML is more easily readable by humans while JSON has a more rigid structure Example: key: value list: - item1 - item2 JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) Definition: A light-weight format for storing and transporting data. Syntactically identical to the code for creating JavaScript objects as it derives from JavaScript Application: - Often used for light-weight data exchange between APIs and web servers - Storing config settings - Used in security tokens JWTs (JSON Web Tokens) for authentication purposes ELIF: A way to store data in text in an organized way instead of XML or binary formats Example: { "id": 1, "name": "Example Item", "enabled": true, "count": 3, "tags": [ "example", "demo" ], "details": { "owner": "Alice", "priority": "medium" } } XML (eXtensible Markup Language) Definition: A language/file structure designed to store and transport data ELIF: Basically HTML but it doesn't do ANYTHING, just information wrapped in tags Application: - XML was designed to carry data, not display them unlike HTML - XML tags and document structure must be defined manually by users - Stores data in plain text format, providing a software & hardware independent way of storing, transporting and sharing data Do not confuse with: HTML Static Definition in Java context: The static members (variable, methods, nested class) belongs to the class itself, not to any specific object (instance) of that class. Definition in website context: Describe pages with fixed content that appears the same to every user, without any real-time, server side processing or interaction with database Definition in IP address context: An IP address that does not change frequently. Used in cases of hosting, web servers and secure communications Base64 Definition: A binary-to-text encoding that uses 64 printable characters, with each character represents 6 bits to maintain integrity of data ELIF: A way of transforming data into clean, safe data that will make sure data does not get change passing through systems Application: - Includes upper/lowercase English letters, digits 0-9 & plus (+) and forward slash (/) - Makes data 33% larger in memory usage, should only use when necessary - Does not contain special characters that might be interpret as special commands - Ensure data doesn't get corrupted when systems expect clean readable texts - Note safe for URL Base32 Definition: A binary-to-text encoding that uses 32 printable chracters, each character are 5 bits in length ELIF: Same shit like Base64 but less bits used Application: - Allow data to be passed to a system that accepts single-byte character input, or UTF-8 encoded string input or appended to a URL without being mangled - Use in URLs as Base64 have those troubling symbols and may be treated specially Parsing Definition: The process of analyzing a sequence of data (string/bytes) into its components (tokens) for computers to work with reliably ELIF: Turning some kind of data into another kind of data but with structures Application: - Apply grammar to tokens to build structure Do not confuse with: - Parsing is not transforming one thing into another, that's the job of the compiler. Parsing is one of the step to compile a program - Parsing does not extract meaning from a text, that's semantic analysis, a step of the compiling process Tokenization Definition: Breaking down stream of characters into smaller, meaningful units called tokens ELIF: Application: - After broken down into tokens --> pass through parser - Part of the broader process of processing raw inputs into structured meaning that your program can work with - Use case in compilers, intepreters, data deserialization, protocol message decoding VPN (Virtual Private Network) Definition: A private network that you can access from anywhere through an encrypted tunnel ELIF: Establish a tunnel between VPN server and you, and send the traffic through there, which the VPN will forward to your intended destination Application: - Can allow you to access restricted content, depending where VPN server is located - Self-host VPNs, allow to access network over the internet securely - If on HTTP, then allow to protect sensitive data and personal informationAllow to work remotely over the internet Virtual Environment Definition: One-line definition. ELIF: Explain Like I'm 5 Application: Do not confuse with: Used in: Offensive, Defensive Ports Definition: One-line definition. ELIF: Explain Like I'm 5 Application: Do not confuse with: Used in: Offensive, Defensive Torrents Definition: One-line definition. ELIF: Explain Like I'm 5 Application: Do not confuse with: Used in: Offensive, Defensive UTF-8 Definition: Character encoding standard for electronic communicatiation. Variable-wdith encoding for Unicode 1-4 bytes long and backward compatible with ASCII ELIF: a fucking table conversion from binary to character sets that supports over a million characters Application: - Efficiently handles all Unicode characters so used in nearly all modern applications Do not confuse with: ASCII as ASCII is 7-bit character encoding standards Terminal Definition: One-line definition. ELIF: Explain Like I'm 5 Application: Do not confuse with: Used in: Offensive, Defensive Shell Definition: One-line definition. ELIF: Explain Like I'm 5 Application: Do not confuse with: Used in: Offensive, Defensive Kernel Definition: One-line definition. ELIF: Explain Like I'm 5 Application: Do not confuse with: Used in: Offensive, Defensive TUI Definition: One-line definition. ELIF: Explain Like I'm 5 Application: Do not confuse with: Used in: Offensive, Defensive

Applications : - Allow humans to easily read or create config files - Typically store things a program would need at run time, without needing to hard code the values ELIF: A general file format to store structured data that's way more readable to humans Do not confuse with: - YAML is a superset of JSON, technically a YAML parser can understand JSON - YAML is more easily readable by humans while JSON has a more rigid structure Example: key: value list: - item1 - item2

docs.text: CVE-2025-55182— React2Shell Summary This vulnerabilit allow RCE in React Server Functions through insecure prototype references Affected Product / Versions: Required configuration (if any): Vulnerability RCE Root Cause - React offers Server Functions (RPC over HTTP), used to fetch data from adjacent peers to ensure low latency, or perform authenticated requests Exploitation (High-Level) Attack vector Preconditions (auth, access, interaction) Broken assumptions Impact CIA impact Privilege or trust boundary crossed Detection Observable indicators or behaviors (high-level). Mitigation Patch / upgrade Config or compensating controls Key Takeaways Concepts reinforced (e.g. trust boundaries, least privilege). References NVD Vendor advisory Independent analysis
